div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Berths can be definitely engaged as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marsailles, Gibraltar, Plymouth and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before.
The express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Wednesday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Friday.
The combined Sea and special train fare is £22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Marseilles.
Passengers having paid full fare in one direction are allowed an abatement of 25 percent on returning within 12 months.
In addition to above regular weekly service there are sailings about twice a fortnightof 5,000 to 7,000 tons steamers to London, calling at Malta or Marseilles.
TO THE EAST

The Mail Steamers leave Suez for Aden and Bombay every Wednesday, and for Australia and China every alternate Wednesday. A steamer leaves for Calcoutta, fortnightly, and another for Japan. Passengers can embark at Port Said.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - CAIRO.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE. In connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez weekly 6 p.m., Wednesday for Port Sudan and Saukin direct returning from Suakin evry Wednesday at noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week to Suakin, Massowah, Hodbidah, Aden. Intermediate steamersdo not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.

div.p: HELOUAN, near CAIRO.

Formerly the favourite Residence of H.H. the late Khedive. Perfect Sanitation.-Purest Desert air. Electric Light. Hot and cold baths attached to most rooms. House warmed by special system of Radiators, adjoinging the Golf Links and Race Course, Tennis, Billards, Garden and open air palm house, good stabling, dark room. Excellent Table. Moderate charges.
Medical Resident Director: ARTHUR J. M. BENTLEY, M.D. - Town Office at Stephenson & Co., Opera Square, Cairo.
26 56-31-3-903 P.E. HERGEL, Manager.

div.p: Full South, Electric Light, opposite Esbekieh Gardens, Large Verandahs, Moderate Charges,
CHAS. BAUER, Proprietor.

The Hotel is beautifully fitted up and is in the most central part of Cairo. Terms for pension fare at the rate of ten shillings a day. Special terms for officers of Army of Occupation. 24,882-31-10-5

div.p: IS NOW OPEN.

div.head: REMARKS.
div.p: To-day the weather appears more settled and warmer than yesterday. The morning opens cloudy, with a light northerly breeze, and a steady barometer. Rain amounting to .14 inch fall after midnight. The humidity has increased.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

SATURDAY, JANUARY 6, 1906.

div.head: FLOREAT ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: The recent scheme propounded by Baron Alfred de Menasce for the embellishment of Alexandria by the creation of a "lung" for the city in the neighbourhood of Ibrahimieh, has attracted a certain amount of attention to the question of making Egypt's commercial Capital a more beautiful and more pleasant city to live in, and there can be no doubt that with the increase of both revenue and capital, likely to accrue before long to the Municipal funds, it is very right that due attention should be given to ornamenting the suburbs of Alexandria. We hear with pleasure of large gardens, or park, to be made from the Government Hospital round the site of the present fortifications to the Moharrem Bey Gate, of another garden round Pompey's Pillar, and a third on the site of the old French Consulate on the Grand-square.

It is also no doubt necessary that a new Municipal building should be constructed, for the very good reason that the prevent Municipal palace does not belong to the town. It was built by public subscription and presented to Ismail Pacha, who decided that it should be a public school. After the fad of Ismail Pacha, the Government for some years found it rather like a white elephant, and as it seemed to be no one's business to pay the schoolmasters, they naturally left, and the place was empty for some years, until the Government lent it provisionally to the Municipality. No doubt the understanding was, that when the latter could afford the outlay, it should provide itself with a suitable building, and we think that the public of Alexandria has some right to expect that this building should revert to its original purpose, and again become a school. Nor should means be wanting for this purpose. The former school not only consisted of a building but of a large piece of land intended as a playground for the scholars. The Municipality has seen fit to one this valuable property for a Museum, and if they wish to keep it as such, it seems only right that they should compensate the school for the use of this ground, and if the latter can no longer have its playground, this land should serve to provide the fonda for the working of the school. Several of our Municipal Councillors are fond of estimating the value of their land on the new quay. Let them estimate with equal liberality and justice the vaine of the site of the Museum, situated as it is in the most aristocratic quarter of the town, and they will find that the school ought to have the means of being set on its legs again in a very efficient manner, and not, as before, without a revenue to maintain it.

We have made rather a lengthy digression, but the subject is an important one, and we shall have more to say about it on another occasion; we merely mention it now to lead up to the opinion, that when the Municipality shall have earned oat the gardens already projected, built a new Municipal palace, endowed and re-started the school on an equitable basis, carried out some system of drainage, and attended to several other matters of greater necessity than ornamental gardens, they will, by that time, have nearly got to the bottom of the Municipal purse, or will not at all events have enough left in it to fall in with Baron de Menasce's ideas and to boy very much land at L.E 2,000 per feddan, even though it were such a desirable site as the low land, on either side of the Ramleh road, which has the great disadvantage of being only about two metres above sea level, and on which at sunset such a miasma often rises, as to make it anything bat a healthy resort Baron A. de Menasce in his scheme speaks of these as the future "lungs" of the towns. We always had an idea that lungs should be within, and not without, the body, and we think that the Municipality is much better inspired is seeking to create them by an extension of the Mohamed Aly-quare and on the site of the fortifications. We trust that our Tower Councillors will in their study of this question take into consideration some of the above remarks. We are pleased on this occasion to remember that when they do commence the study of a question, they do not usually arrive at any decision in hot haste.

div.head: Greek Hospital
div.p: Mr. C. Achillopoulo has given £1,000 for the proposed Greet hospital at Abbassieh.

div.head: Accession Day
div.p: On the occasion of the anniversary of the Khedive's accession, H. E the Governor will hold a reception at the Gouvernorat on Monday from 9 a m. till noon.

div.head: Merchant Seamen's Home.
div.p: The New Year's Treat given annually in the Merchant Seamen's Home by the Ramleh ladies has been fixed to take place on the 26th inst., and is being organised by Mrs. Moss.

div.head: St. Andrew's Church, Alexandria.
div.p: The Sacrament of the Lord's Supper will be celebrated in St. Andrew's Church, at the close of the morning service, tomorrow. Visitors and friends are cordially invited as usual.

div.head: Mena House Case.
div.p: Judgment in the pre-emption case, brought by Dr. Rifky Pacha and his wife against George Nungovich Bay in regard to the purchase of Mena House Hotel, will be given on Tuesday next.

div.head: Poutrel-Davey Case.
div.p: The hearing of the Hon. A.J. Davey's appeal against the verdict of the Cairo Mixed Tribunal in the action brought by M. Poutrel against him for wrongful dismissal has bean postponed till February 14.

div.head: Cashier Sentenced.
div.p: The Greek Assize Court at Alexandria sentenced Jean Platidis, cashier, to fifteen months' imprisonment on Thursday for having embezzled £200 belonging to Mr. Alfred Dale of Mansourah.

div.head: Change of Address,
div.p: Messrs. Orenstein and Koppel have transferred their offices in Cairo to Chareh Madabegh (Immeuble Coronel) near the National Bank and their Alexandria offices to 5, rue Porte Rosette.

div.head: Pianoforte Recital.
div.p: Mme Bonucci-Carlesimo, a pianist who has few equals, and who delighted us at Alexandria recently, will give a recital at the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo, on Wednesday next, 10th inst., commencing at 5.30 p.m.

div.head: Financial Circular.
div.p: Mesirs. H. de Vries and Boutigny, stock and share brokers, Cairo, publish daily a detailed report of the stock market. This circular, which also contains a great deal of financial information, is sent gratis on application.

div.head: Cairo Trotting Races.
div.p: The committee of the Cairo Trotting Club met at the Grand Continental Hotel on Thursday and elected Ishak Bey Hussein president, Ahmed Bey Bakri vice president, and Hussein Bey Sioufi secretary. It was decided to bold a meeting on the 28th inst.

div.head: New Year's Gifts
div.p: Mr. N. Spathis, the mineral water manufacturer at Cairo, is distributing a memorandum tablet, and the Lowenbraueri is presenting its Egyptian clients with a diary. The Palatine Insurance Company and Tennent's Pilsener Beer are issuing useful calendars.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: The imports of coal into Alexandria during 1905 amounted to 1,046,811 tons, as compared with 1,057,441 during 1904 Wales sent 575,441 tons, Newcastle 227,879, the Scotch districts 119,294, and Yorkshire 78,636 while the imports of other qualities came to 45,561 tons.

div.head: Caisse Hypothécaire.
div.p: The Cairo Bourse Committee yesterday officially quoted the shares if the Caisse Hypothécaire d'Egypte for the first time. Hitherto these shares had been only quoted at Brussels and Antwerp. The financial year of this company, which closed four days ago, has been very prosperous.

div.head: St. Mark's and All Saints'.
div.p: At the morning and evening services of both churches on Sunday next (to-morrow) the collections will be given to the Maternity Home, Alexandria. The preacher at St. Mark's at 11 a.m. will be the Rev H.G.G. Rorison, B.A., R.N., chaplain of H.M.S. Minerva, who exchanges duty with Canon Ward.

div.head: Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: The performance of Les Travaux d'Hercule, a new opera-bouffe, by the French operetta company at the Alhambra, has been deferred to Monday. This evening La Fille du Tambour Major will be given. To-morrow, La Petite Mariée will be played in the afternoon and (for the last time) Les Saltimbanques in the evening.

div.head: Murders at Assiout.
div.p: The body of a soldier was found, three days ago, in a street of Assiout, and the ghaffirs and the sheikh of the quarter, in which the murder took palace, were suspected of the crime. The day after the discovery of the corpse a Sudanese was also murdered in the same spot. This second tragedy has considerably alarmed the authorities at Assiout. The authors of these two murders are still unknown.

div.head: Children's Matinee.
div.p: As already announced, a children's matinée performance will be given at the Zizinia Theatre on Sunday next for the benefit of the Alexandria Conservatoire. We understand that Signa Gamma Bellincioni has kindly offered to assist, the ladies of the committee. The great artiste will sell tombola tickets in the theatre and will preside at the drawing of prizes. Children will be invited on the stage. It is expected that the "matinée" will draw a big house.

div.head: RUSSIAN INSURRECTION. IN ITS DEATH THROES. SIGNS OF THE TRICE OF GOD.
div.p: The St. Petersburg correspondent of the "Daily Telegraph," whose contributions to his paper have not been characterised by any undue optimism, to-day describes the Russian insurrection as being in its death throes. The many Christmas trees and festivities, which are being held throughout the country are, he says, signs of the truce of God.

div.head: THE GRAND CADI.
div.p: Sheikh Yehia, Grand Cadi of Egypt, arrived at Alexandria from Constantinople this morning. He will probably proceed to Cairo this afternoon.

div.head: THE NEW ASYLUM
div.p: We hear that the Public Health Department has definitely decided to construct the new asylum at Khanka, and has applied to the Ministry of Finance for a grant of 200 feddans for a site. The site has already been chosen and the Department will commence work very shortly.

div.head: THE PRICE OF SALT.
div.p: Some feeling has been caused by the fact that certain grocers in Upper Egypt, who are agents for the Salt & Soda Co., are selling salt at over 2mm. per kilo, in spite of the engagement into which the Salt & Soda Company entered into with the Government, viz., to sell salt at not more than 2mm. the kilo, which took effect from the 1st January.

These agents plead that, having bought large stocks at fixed prices before January 1, they cannot dispose of them at the over rate without loss. As a matter if fact, the agents had ample warning from the company, which is not in any way responsible for their conduct, and we imagine that individuals wishing to protest against the high price have only to bring the matter before the Government or the Salt and Soda Company to have their grievance remedied.

div.head: THE ARBAGI OF CAIRO.
div.p: A Cairo correspondent writes : It would be an immense relief if the Inspector of Traffic would be kind enough to enforce only a legitimate use of the whip by the native arbagi. As it is one continual crack, crack ; or crack, crack, crack ; painful to the animals, painful to see, and painful to hear.

div.head: THE BEARING REIN.
div.p: A correspondent writes:- It can only be a matter of regret to lovers of horses that the bearing-rein is used so extensively in Alexandria. Quite the larger proportion of horses in private carriages have to endure this torturing addition to their harness, and one can see in a moment by the constant tossing and jerking of their heads how fretted and worried they are by the hateful bearing-rein. In many cases one feels sure that it is only inattention on the part of the owner, who leaves all details of the stable, etc., to his servants, and not cruelty deliberately practised to made his turn-out look smart. If these few, and not at all I fear eloquent, words are read by anyone who allows his coachman to use a bearing-rein, I ask him for a moment to consider the suffering inflicted on the noble and willing animals he owns. Animals are only given one life ; why should not that one life be happy and comfortable, considering all the use and pleasure they afford us? Until recently the horses in arabiehs were exempt from bearing- reins, the evil is spreading to them to add another burden to their already well-laden backs. A jaded chestnut was noticed the other day in Bulkeley tightly reined up ; the driver, on having the cruelty of his action pointed out to him, civilly unstrapped the poor beast, who immediately stretched his neck with relief. The man explained that he thought it made the horse strong, as Dr. … and Mrs. … (naming two influential persons) always drove their horses like that. People may say there are bearing-reins and bearing-reins. Quite true, there are different forms, bat everyone of them, leather or elastic, tends to ruin the months, and are a constant source of fret, worry, and torture, to the unfortunate horses who have to endure them.

div.head: OF INTEREST TO-TRAVELLERS
div.p: Naples is yearly becoming a great port of embarkation and disembarkation for Egypt and we are glad to learn that the numerous robberies and assaults upon foreigners at Naples have caused the municipal authorities to issue notifie irions premising more active suppression of rapacity this season for visitors. This will be welcome pews to tourists, as in no other part of Europe are there so many railway and hotel robberies as in Italy. The average British and American tourist traveller on the Continent is invariably regarded by the natives as being enormously wealthy, and in consequence suffers far more from theft and extortion than the visitor from any other country. Arrangements have now been made by the Neapolitan authorities to have a municipal guard stationed at the door of every hotel and museum at the railway stations, and landing places, simply as a safeguard for visitors,

div.head: THE SUCRERIES.
div.p: IMPORTANT DECISION.
CERTAINTY OF CONCORDAT.

The Sucreries case came before the Commercial Chamber of the Cairo Mixed Courte this morning and in accordance with the request of the legal representatives of the company, the case was referred back to the juge-commis, to await the result of the vote to be given at the creditors meeting of February 10.
This decision is highly important for we hear that if the creditors agree—and we are assured that they are in agreement—the concordat is morally certain to be granted.

div.head: ANGLO AMERICAN CO.
div.p: The fusion of the Anglo-American Nile Steamer and Hotel Company with the Hamburg- America Line was adopted at the extraordinary general meeting of the former company held in Cairo yesterday. The company will assume the style of the Hamburg and Anglo-American Nile Company from the 1st May next.

div.head: THE LATE MRS. MOND.
div.p: Luxor, Thursday.
The body of Mrs. R. Moud, who died last week after an illness of only three days' duration, has been embalmed and sent to England for burial.

Mr. A. D. Alban, H. B. M.'s Consul in Cairo, came up specially and held an inquest on the body previous to embamment. The result of the inquest has not transpired, but some uncertainty seems to surround the lady's death.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive returns to Koubbeh this evening and will go to Abdeen for the Accession Day reception on Monday morning. In the afternoon his Highness will review the troops at Abbassieh.

Great preparations are being made for the Accession Day fêtes at Cairo. The Esbekieh Garden has been decorated with bunting. The tents and lamps are already in situ, and the committee, who have received subscriptions amounting to over LE 1,000, expect to give an entertainment to the public that will be worthy of the 12th anniversary of the accession of H.H. Abbas Helmy II. A kiosque, where a military band will play, has been erected in front of the Opera, flags brighten all the chief streets, and many houses are hanging out national flags. Only warmth and sunlight are required to make the fêtes a success.

div.head: IRRIGATION DEPARTMENT.
div.p: It is reported that Mr. Verschoyle will replace Mr. Clowes, who will resign his post as Inspector General of Irrigation for Upper Egypt on June 1, 1906. In that ease a successor will have to be found for Mr. Verschoyle, who is at present Inspector General of Irrigation for Lower Egypt, for it would be hardly possible for one official to look after the combined inspectorates. We have not, however, heard any official confirmation of the above-mentioned report.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.
div.p: The following is from "Al Sabah": From time time we hear of some new scheme of the Alexandria Municipality for beautifying the city. It is intended to open gardens and public promenades because the Municipal Councillors think the city is in need of such things. But the Councillors seem to be quite oblivious of the huge amount of misery that exists in Alexandria, where hundreds of wretched, poverty- stricken creatures are to be seen thronging the streets, begging everywhere and anywhere for some crust of bread for their sustenance. The Councillors of the Alexandria Municipality seem to be unaware of these sights. If they were they would spend a portion of the city's money in bettering the lot of these unhappy beings instead of increasing the comfort and pleasures of the richer classes by making pleasure gardens and such-like things. If the members of the Municipality do not pay attention to the submerged class of the population, we must perforce believe that they do not possess any feelings of humanity, and yet they appear to he inspired by some worthy sentiments. We accordingly urge the Municipality to have some ideas of the duties it owes to the poor and we beg our contemporaries in the local Press to do their utmost to impress the Municipality with these ideas.

div.head: BAND PERFORMANCE.
div.p: In honour of the Khedive's accession, and by kind permission of Lient.-Colonel R. C. C. Cox, commanding, and officers 2nd Batt. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, the band will perform the following selection of music on the terrace, Grand Continental Hotel, on Monday from 8 to 10 p.m :—
March-Greetings to Egypt Tobani.
Overt ire—Fra Davolo Auber.
Mazurka Militaire Sabre au Clair Wissa.
Se action La Poupee Audrad.
Valse The Giver of Years Liddle.
Patrol The Crack egiment Totant.
Selection Th Spring Chicken— er 11 and Monckton.
March Sorella Botel-Clerc.
Regimental March Khedivial Anthem - God Save the King.
B. Watson Ramsey, Bandmaster.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The Ellerman S. S. Ararat sailed from Malta last night and is expected here on Tuesday morning with passengers, mails and general cargo.

div.head: IRRIGATION NEEDS.
div.p: YOUSSEF CANAL TO BE ENLARGED.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
Medinet el-Fayoum, Friday.

The new irrigation programme for this province is very satisfactory and the staff of irrigation engineers in the Fayoum appear to be very capable men. A scheme is to be carried out for improving irrigation in those villages which form the centre of the province such as Kallobeen, Sileen, Agmin, etc, the Bahr Youssef Canal is to be enlarged for this purpose.

div.head: A POSTAL NEED
div.p: A large number of leading residents in the capital of this province have begged me to use the wide publicity of your columns for the purpose of craving a much-desired boon from the authorities of the Egyptian Postal Administration. The great postal desiderata of Medinet el-Fayoum are post-boxes, for the city is growing space and many important and new streets have arisen and as yet entirely lack post-boxes for letters. It is most inconvenient to have to trudge to the Post Office.

div.head: FAYOUM STATION.
div.p: Many merchants here complain bitterly of the treatment their goods receive at the railway station. A lawyer here, Atria Effendi, told me that two tins of cheese had been sent to him and he discovered that the employés at the station had consumed more than half of the contents.

div.head: THE LIGHT RAILWAY.
div.p: Mr. Michael Fanos, a friend of George Bey Wissa, has arrived at Melinet-el-Fayonm with a long petition addressed to the authorities of the Ministry of the Interior against the management of the Fayoum Light Railway. Many of the notables here have signed the petition.

div.head: THE MISSION GIRLS' SCHOOL
div.p: To-day was the prize-day of the girls' school, which is under the direction of Mr. Reid and Mr. Baid, and everybody who is anybody put in an appearance. The girls recited and answered the questions put to them in a most satisfactory manner and looked very happy in their nice white dresses. I was much pleased with the intelligence the girls showed in the debate. The subject was "After School, What ?" Their knowledge of English is excellent, though in some cases their pronunciation is faulty, and this will, I hope, be remedied in the near future. Some of their needlework exhibits were first rate. Miss Martin, the school-mistress, is heavily to be congratulated on the success of her training.

div.head: FAYOUM WATER POWER
div.p: The Ministry of the interior and the Ministry of Public Works have undertaken to officially consider the scheme for making use of the waterfalls in the Fayoum province for lighting the town by electricity. Electricity is being developed by means of a fall in one instance in the Fayoum. In 1903 the lake at Tamiyah was run off by inserting two wrought- iron pipes, each 1.50 metres diameter, through the old retaining wall : this was done to improve the drainage of the Rodah and the Rubiyat lands. There is a considerable fall in the discharge from these pipes as, which has been utilized by Boghos Pacha Nubar to drive a turbine for the development of electrical power to work a ginning, factory.

div.head: THE SEASON AT LUXOR.
div.p: Luxor, Thursday.

The season here is now in full swing. Karnak Hotel is ready to accommodate the overflow visitors from the Luxor Hotel. It is very pleasant to spend an afternoon in the garden of any of the local hotels, the weather being "heavenly," to quote the young ladies. A trip to the valley of the tombs of the kings or a donkey ride to Karnak, is not the least of the attractions open to visitors. The races which were hell to-day were a huge success in every way.

div.head: SUDAN ABYSSINIAN TRADE
div.p: The development of the trade between Abyssinia and the Sudan is clearly evidenced by the reports of the French Agents at Djibouti, who are beginning to find that a great quantity of produce which it was hoped would find an outlet by the Red Sea, is now being taken inland and sent to Khartoum. Hitherto all attempts to trade with Abyssinia by European Powers have naturally had to be made by way of the sea shore, and it is not always with success that efforts hare been made to open up the country by "pacific penetration." But since the barbarism of the Sudan was crushed a great trade has gradually grown up between Khartoum and Western Abyssinia, which is developing with marvellous rapidity. The Sudanese Government has supported the Nile Navigation Companies in their efforts to draw the trade of Ethiopia towards the interior, and to make the Nile and its tributaries take their proper place as the highway of commerce in that part of Africa. The population of Western Abyssinia has always enjoyed the reputation of being most unfavourable to European influence, and of being unwilling to enter into any other relations with its neighbours, but the Sudan does not approach them as a conqueror, but as abrader, and it has shown them the advantages which are to be obtained by an interchange of commodities.

div.head: NOTES FROM HELOUAN.
div.p: A "SHOCING" AFFAIR.
FIGHT FOR A LADY'S FORTUNE.
( FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT ).
Helouan, Friday.

This week the cold has been very great here. On Wednesday afternoon the wind was so strong that some tents and shades here and there in the town were upset. Practically all engagements and arrangements for the afternoon met with the same fate, as also did the tempers of a good many of the persons concerned. Things have improved generally since. Tourists are arriving from Europe and America, and the town is gradually filling.

There was a rumour recently current that the Delta Company intended to improve matters in connection with their Helouan branch. It is to be hoped that the rumour was well-founded for the carriages are dusty and badly lighted. One evening last week, the second-class saloon passengers had to make the first half of the journey from Cairo in semi darkness and the second half in complete obscurity. To add to the discomfort when, nearing Helouan the carriage gave a violent lurch, which caused many of the passengers to fear that an attempt had been made to wreck the train. Happily, such was not a case, the shock being probably due to a stone which had rolled down to the permanent way. A better look-out for such occurrences should be kept.

A lady who recently died in the town has, it is understood, left the enormous sum of about half a million pounds to the Russian church. At first, she had made a will bequeathing practically all her wealth to her children, but after the visit of a priest, the will was changed, a huge sum being left to the church. Subsequently, further representations were made in the interests of the children, and in the end the sum left to the church was reduced to the amount already mentioned.

div.head: MOTOR 'BUSES FOR CAIRO.
div.p: There will be an extraordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the Cairo Omnibus Company on the 16th inst. for the purpose of sanctioning the fusion of this company with the Automobile Transport Company of Cairo, now in course of formation. The capital of the latter company is £100,000 in 25,000 shares of £1 each. Each share of the Omnibus Company will be exchanged for 3 1/4 shares of the Automobile Company.

div.head: EMANCIPATION OF EGYPT.
div.p: To the Editor of the Egyptian Gazette.

Sir,—It is not the first time that accusations similar to that of which "Observer" complains have been made and those accused have been content to leave the public in Europe to appreciate them. Authors, like everyone else, most make money, in order to live, and it is well known that several have also found Egypt a very "happy hunting ground." They must, however, recognise that their books are getting stale since they find it necessary to put a foreign label on them.—Yours truly,
READER.
Alexandria, 4th January 1906.

div.head: BACCARAT A GAME OF CHANCE.
div.p: Baccarat is such a favourite game in Egypt, especially at Alexandria, that its many votaries here will be much interested in a judgement pronounced by the Brussels Appeal Court on the 27th ulto. in favour of the appellants in the case of the Ostend Gambling Club. The Lower Court has sentenced the manager of the Ostend Kursaal and several of his assistants to various penalties for infringement of the law against gambling in public places. The appeal against this sentence was based, among other points, on the contention that baccarat is not a game of hazard. Many expert witnesses were called to demonstrate the theories of statisticians on the game, but, not withstanding, various ingenuous contentions of the counsel for the appellants, the Court of Appeal decided that baccarat mast be regarded as hazardous. The conviction of the manager and his servants was reversed nevertheless, the Court holding that it was not proved that he had organised a gambling club under the meaning of the Act, as, although he used means to attract strangers to join the club, and charged an entrance fee to the club, it could not be shown that he benefited personally by the gambling, or that the club fees did more than cover the expenses of the establishment. Regarding the continual playing of baccarat in the Kursaal Club, the Court laid it down that this only proved the presence of professional gamblers in the slab. The result of the decision seems to be that in the private club of the Kursaal gambling can be continued without fear of penalties under the anti gambling law.

div.head:
THE ARMY REORGANISATION.
EXPENSES OF THE NATION.

div.p: At Derby, Mr. Chamberlain, alter fighting with continuous interruptions for nearly an hour, was shouted down. His speech, which was on the subject of Colonial preference, was practically inaudible.

Speaking in the City, Mr. Haldane announced that Sir Henry Campbell-Bannerman had given him a free hand to re-organise the army. He said that Sir Henry laid such stress on efficiency that he was prepared, if he thought it requisite, to spend more to get more men.

Speaking at Sheffield, Mr. Asquith said that the expanses of the nation have increased by £43,000,000 in ten years, of which half was for the army and navy. A wide field exists for the reduction of taxes, including those on coal, tea, sugar, and the income tax.
(Reuter)
The "Echo de Paris" says that King Edward and Emperor William have exchanged letters expressing ideas which are clearly pacific and conciliatory. (Havas)

div.head:
CONDITION OF RUSSIA
REVOLUTION NOT REPRESSED

div.p: Advices from Russia continue to report serious troubles in varions parts of the Empire, showing that the revolution is in no wise wholly repressed. A bomb was thrown at the chief of police at Radom, carrying off his legs, and killing his wife.
(Reuter)

div.head:
LABOUR CRISIS IN SPAIN.
MARKETS BEING LOOTED

div.p: The labour crisis in Spain is becoming alarming notably at Seville and Xeres, where –mishing(ink is smudged) workmen are looting the markets. (Ink Smudge) is being organised.
(Reuter)

div.head: THREATENED FINANCIAL PANIC IN U. S. A.

div.p: The well-known banker Schiff, in a speech delivered here, has predicted a panic exceeding all previous experiences, unless the currency is made more elastic. This speech has produced a great impression.
(Reuter)

div.head:
STRICTURE AND KIDNEY DISEASE
HOW BEER AFFECTED THE KIDNEYS.
div.p: CURED 2 YEARS AGO—STILL WELL TO DAY.
54 Brighton Place, Hampton Square,
Sheen Lane, Mortlake,
London, England.

For nearly 19 years I suffered from stricture and kidney disease, and many a time have I laid on the bedroom floor writhing in agony. Twice I have been in hospital and undergone operations for the stricture. Never, as long as I live, shall I forget what I went through then. The doctors said I could not live another three months, yet I can truly say that, although two years have passed since then, I was never better in my life than I am to-day.

My illness came on in this way : One day at my work I strained by back, and afterwards I suffered from severe cutting pains, just over where the kidneys are, especially when I stooped. I could not sleep well at nights, and there were distressing urinary disorders. I was miserable and out of sorts, and although the doctor did all he could for me, I get worse instead of better. If I had a glass of beer it irritated my kidneys so much that I had to keen to my bed for a week, but since using Doan's Backache Kidney Pills I can enjoy my glass without feeling a bit the worse for it.

It wasn't until I had finished the fourth box of Doan's Pills that they seemed to be doing me any good, but I persisted with the medicine, and with the fifth box there was a decidedly freer action of the bladder. No other medicine had ever helped me at all, and you can imagine how delighted I was at this relief. For six months I continued with Doan's Backache Kidney Pills, and then I was entirely cared of the stricture and kidney disease. From that day to this there hasn't been any sign of the old complaints returning.
My suffering and my cure are well-known to hundreds of men I have worked with in London, and I am sure that had 1 not used Doan's Backache Kidney Pills when I did, I should never have lived.
(Signed) GEO. PRIEST.

Doan's Backache Kidney Pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists at P.T. 13 per box, or P.T. 71 for 6 boxes ; or they may be had direct from the general agent for Egypt,— Max Fischer, Hotel du Nil Street, Mousky, Cairo.

div.head: General Post Office.
div.p: IMPORTANT NOTICE.

Owing to the fact that former notices referring to clear direction of correspondence have been largely disregarded by the public and that the general delivery has had to be delayed in consequence, it has been decided that from 1st February 1906, correspondence for house delivery addressed only "Cairo" or "Alexandria" will be retarded and only sorted after the first delivery of each mail has left the Post Offices in those towns.
After that date it will be no longer necessary to make special requests for house to house delivery as correspondence bearing the full address will be duly delivered.

Crown 4tc, 400 pp. 720 Illustrations PRICE 21s. net.
A New Issue has been found necessary within Six Months.
Letter from Sir Rudolf von Slatin.

Dear Mr. Ward,—Your delightful and most interesting book on the Sudan has reached me. I congratulate you heartily on the excellent manner in which the work is written and illustrated. All of us who have done our little best to regenerate the country, after its terrible misfortunes, have received more than kind treatment at your hands. I don't suppose anyone realises more than I do the change that has coma over the Sudan since my old and tyrannical master the Khalifa disappeared from the scene. Your description of the 'Peace and Progress' is a sequel to my 'Fire and Sword in the Sudan.' ,
With kindest regards, believe me,
yours sincerely,
6-3 RUDOLF V SLATIN

Le Banque d'Athènes a eu divers soubresauts eu sympathie avec le marché de Paris. Elis finit demand, e à 131 1/2.
Le Comptoir Finanoiet et Commercial olôtoro à 4 3/8. eu bans e de 3/16 sur le cours de la semaine dernière.
Le Cassa di 8oonto reste à pen près an même cours que vendredi dernier, soit 214 l'ancienne émission et 210 la nouvelle.
En Land Bank la clôture a lien en reprise à 8 3/16, tandis qn'en Banqne d'Abyssinie elle s'effectue en baisse à 6 15/16.
Le Béhéra finit extournent an même prix que la semair e dernière, o'est-à-dire à 85 1/4.
L'Oasis (Corporation of Western Egypt) reste stationnaire à 31/32, tandis que l'Invest- ment reprend de 1 5/32 à 1 3/16, le Trust de 1 1/8 à 1 3/16 et la Delta Land de 2 1/16 à 2 3/16.
De 17 1/16 la Daira 8anieh rebondità 17 6/8 après avoir atteint an moment 17 3/4.

Tandis qne la Brasserie des Pyramides a perdu 3 francs à 115 la Privilégiée, 1* Crown Brewery a gagné dans le même temps 9 francs à 215. Cette dernière avait même touché hier le prix de 218. Quant anx Dividendes, elles restent » peu près stationnaires.
Les petites valeurs oommeroiaies et industrielles, telles que la Filature, les Cotton Mills, les Markets, et la Sait and Soda, demeurent sensiblement à leurs oours antérieurs.
A 5 11/16 l'Anglo American Nile perd 1/16.
Depuis que son oonpon a été détaché, la Khédivial Mail n'a guère fait parler d'elle La Privilégiée clôture à 4 3/8, soit en baisse de 1/16 et l'Ordinary à 24/6 ex.
Les Eaux du Caire sont invariables à 116 et 245 , mais l'Alexandria Water gagne 1/8 à 14 1/4.
Les Tramways d'Alexandrie, Privilégiée et Dividende, finissent exaotement anx mêmes prix que la semaine passée.
Le 24 du mois dernier a en lieu l'Assemb'és des actionnaires de l'Egyptian Sait A Soda. Lés propositions du oonaeil d'admintstration y comp is la dividende de 4 %, ont tontes été approuvées.

div.head: REVUE COMMERCIALE
div.p: Coton

Les affaires se sont encore une fois ressenties des effets de la période fériés qae nous tra-1 versons, car, tout comme la semaine précé-i dente, la séance de Samedi matin a été éoourtée et pour la journée de hindi, à.l'oooa-1 sion du nouvel an, il y a eu chômage ooœJ plet. Mais si à cause de ces continuelles' interruptions l'aotivité a'laissé quelque peu1 à désirer, il n'eu éstpae moins vrai que lest changements imprévus qui nona ont été aviséd de l'Amérique et les qrtë'queé dépêcha» plu»! ou moins sensatidnnelles reçues de New York ont été suffisants pour tenir en haleine lai spéculation da notre plaoe et pont rendre lai semaine relativement intéressante.

Pour ommencer, par suite de la baissé de 13 points venae en clôture d'Amérique; la première journée a été pen animée et aved la faiblesse qui a prédominé, les oonrs ont] fini par perdra 3/32 sür la veille.

Ssns nouvelles de l'Etranger poor noué guider.nnus avons débnté. à la reprise d«j affai res mardi matin très oalmes et en mauvaise tendanoe, et de fait, à la fin de la journée,' la cote noos a montré une nouvelle perte ulté rienre de 3/16 de tallari, oe qui mettait le Janvier à 16 1/16 et le Mars à 15 7/16.

Jasques-lè, les choses n'avaient prooédé quel d'une façon tont à-fait normal^' ear le joué même Liverpool, de son côté, avait joliment! baissé ; mais oe qui a été ane véritable surpriseï pour tont le monde, o'est la fermeté qui a pré-' dominé le lendemain, fermeté qui a été attri-1 buée anx gros ordres d'achats qui teraient venus du Caire pour oompte de la spéculation de l'intérienr. Le fait est que malgré 1er nouveau recul d'Amérique, o'est sur la cote dei 15 9/32 pour le janvier et 15 21/32 pour le mars que nous avons olôturé ce soir-là.

Hier, jeudi, quoiqu'on changement poori le mieux sur les Américains nona ait été an-' noncé, la matinée a été oalme, mais le soir ane amélioration de 1/32 à 1/16 a été enregistrée! sur tontes les échéances, et cela sur l'avis que Misa Qiles avait lanoé -une dernière estimation de la réoolte de 10.200.000 Balles Seulement, presque simultanément à cette information, d'antres dépêobe» noua out appris que, suivant an oablogrsmms da correspondent du "Daily Mail" à New-York, les pronostics pour le rapport d'égrensge du Census Bureau, attendu le 8 coursât sont de 9.800.000 Balles au premier Janvier, et oomme oes deux nouvelle] s'annulaient entre elles, notre marché n'a fait ancnn oas de l'une, ni de l'autre, oomme aussi il n'a pris nullement en considération la hausse de 12 à 14 points reçaeoe matin d'A mériqne, et s'est laissé aller à son penohant naturel du moment, résultant da désir des haussiers de réaliser on de s'alléger, d'antant pins qne Liverpool n'a guère été brillant aujourd'hui En résumé, les derniers oonrs de os soir sont de 15 7/32 le janvier et 15 6/8 le mars avec tendance faible.
La 1ère filière de Janvier a été da Caotars 22,000 ; elle n'est paa énorme, mais elle a suffi quand même ponr élargir le report de Janvier à Mars.

En comparant oes oonrs avec oenx de Vendredi dernier, none nous trouvons en perte de 1/8 et de 3/32 respectivement pour les deux mois sus-mentionnés et oe réanltat est d'antant pins frappant qne, dans le même laps de temps, les fluctuations de l'Amériqne ont abouti an retour à la oote ds la semaine passée, vendredi soir, et cela à un point près.—Comme on le voit dono, l'inflnenoe de l'Etranger n'a nullement été oontinue sur nous et notre marché semble plutôt impressionné par le mai que de toute oontre-partie sérieuse chaque f >is que les haussiers veulent vendre. Le fait est que sacs an revirement inattendu du dehors, les détenteurs de oontrats sur notre plaoe finiront par montrer ane fatigae, dont les oonséqaences ne sont pas difficiles à prévoir.

Notre situation d'ailleurs est presque identique à celle de l'Amérique, où les idées n'ont pas l'air de s'être modifiées, la grande majorité ne oessant de oroire à la baisse, tont en expliquant le revirement de oes junta derniers par les raohata du petit découvert anxieux de s'assnrer ses bénéfioes.—Il est positif que ponr le moment les apparenoes ne sont pas favorables à l'article, mais cela durera-t-il longtemps 1 II est permis d'en douter, car la spéculation Amérioaine ne pourra pas se tenir tranquille, surtont si l'horizon politique vient s'éclaircir et la crise monétaire à s'améliorer. Et pais n'oabllons pas oe qae nous disions dans nos précédentes revuêe, à savoir, qne la baisse aura toujours le don de faire surgir de nouveaux aoheteurs et de ramener la filature aux aohats, oe qui ferait ohanger du tout au tout les dispositions et les raisonne ment» du jour.

De nonvean, la tenue de la nouvelle réoolte a été meilleure qne oetle de l'anoienne et le rapprochement entre le Novembre et le Janvier B'est aocentné de 1/8. Ponr pen qne la faiblesse dure, la différencie aotuelle diminuera enoore davantage, attendu que, soit par suite de l'intérêt que montra la filature pour la prochaine réoolte, soit par suite dea arbitrages faits entre les deux réooRes sur une assez large éohelle, en peut être enoore à oause des trans farts oontioneU des position» spéculatives sur les éohéanoes les plus éloignées, le Novembre a toutes les chances dé maintenir ses oonrs on de ne suivre qne partiellement toute baisse sé rieuse qui viendrait à se produire sur la vieille réoolte.

Le marché du disponible a été irrégulier et peut-être peu aotif ; dans tous les oas, faible au début, il fiuit soutenu et même en hausse de 1/8 sur les bons Mit-Afifi et les Proveoanoes Hsnte-Egypte. La demande da la part de la filature n'est pas très snivie, ti l'on veut, mais en somme, soit d'an oôté, soit de l'àntre, il y a toujours dea ordres et oela se oomprend, si l'on prend en considération la modération de l'écart existant entre Américains et Egyptiens et la bonne marche de oes derniers.

Lee exportations, quoique supérieuresà oellea da l'année dernière, n'ont pas atteint les pro- nostioi, mais il parslt qu'il y a en du retard daus certains embarquements ou dana certains règlements aveo la Douane, oe qui n'a pas permis d'iuolore dana le relevé de oe matin des quantités assez importance] partant cette semaine. Si le fait est vrai, il y aura ample oompensa- rioa vendre li prochain. Daus tous les cas, il ne faut pas espérer dépss'er les chiffras de l'année dernière, les expéditions de la hnitaine à venir en 1985 ayant été de 29,000 Balles. Ponr la semaine qui vient de finir, les totaux respect!fe ont été de 18 0)0 et de 16,00 > Balles.

Liverpool a montré un peu plus d'entrain pour nos ootocs, les ventes de ôette semaine ayant été vn peu plus forte-, que «elles de la huitaine préèédente. Quant aux prix, il n'y a pas grand' ohose à mettre en évidence, toutes les différenciée depuis vendredi consistant simplement en one haisfe de 1/16 sut le disponible et en une hausse de 2/01 sur le3 futurs. Les Ainérioains aussi out été l'objet d'tme meilleuredemande eu disponib'e * Livevpoul, et pour os qui est dsS ou tarions, le oàk est fe même que pour nos coton-, là èote du junfr ne montrant en somme que l on 2 points de moins que la finale de la semaine passée.

Manchester tre signale rien de particioulier mais l'Amérique cible pour se p la ha tre de la consommation, ce qui a se raison d'etre si l'on s'arrête à ses retraits actuels, sans tenir compte de ses approvisiomenent en magasin.
Noua appelons l'attention de nos leoteora sur les résumés et antres tableanx qu'ils trouveront en seconde page.

div.head: Graines da Coton
div.p: La demanda pour le disponible n'a ooaié d'être excellente, ce qui a en ponr effet de faire hausser les prix d'antant plus facilement que les oontrats ont été en amélioration sensible. La fait est qae la marchandise prête se paie aujourd'hui P.T. 61 et qae la tendanoe est bonne.

Le manqne de place anx qnaia a entravé les embarquements, mais cela, au fond ne; oonstitae qu'un simple retard, les affrètements étant nombreux ponr Janvier, avec perspectives de qnelqces nouveaux steamers à ajouter à 1a liste déjà oonnne.

En attendant, le monvement de la réoolte est satisfaisant : nos lecteurs pourront s'en rendre "oompte en jetant un coup d'œil sur les chiffres et autres renseignements oonoer- nant l'article, que nous publions on pen pins loin, en deuxième page.

La graine a été en faveur auprès de 1a spéculation qui y prend, de jour en jour, pins d'intérêt. Le Caire aussi s'en est mêlé et aujourd'hui, oela est incontestable, il existe sur les graines des positions relativement importantes et qui pourraient peut-être permettra par la suite de manœuvrer le marohé, si la consommation aotuelle venait à se maintenir. En attendant, les oonrs ont monté de P.T. 2 pendant cette semaine et la tendanoe reste poor la hausse. Comme activité, il y s eu on assez bon oonrant d'affaires.

L'Angleterre n'a nullement été réaaloitrante à la hausse de notre marché et l'ou affirme que Hall a payé jusqu'à £6 1/3. Depuis il y a eu un peu de réaotion, sans préjaiioe de la demande, mais aveo la fermeté d'Alexandrie, une petite reprise semb'e plutôt probable.

On dit que 1er ornshsrs ont largement achetéqiour se garantir oontre tonte surprise ; œla est pentêtre vrai, mais qui noos garantit qu'il ne s'agit pas d'approvisionnements anticipés, an lieu d'une augmentation effective de la consommation ? E it-oe que la situation ds la graine de Un a'eit modifiée et a oassé de favoriser la graine de octon 1 Bu face du manque da toute nouvelle à oe sujet, il est permis de répandre par la négative.

div.head: Circulaire H. de Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES
Caire, 5 janvier.

A Londres, le Consolidé est resté hier invarié h 89 J malgré les préoccupations causées par les nouvelles pessimistes répandues au sujet de la question du Maroc. Mais les valeurs égyptiennes sont toutes renseignées en réaction, ce qui est explicable après la iorte poussée de oes jours derniers et les réalisations qn'elle a dd déterminer.
Ainsi la National Bank a perdu 1/4 de livre h 26 1/4 ; l'Agncole et la Daira 1/8 respectivement à 9 5/8 et 17 5/8.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier a, par coutre, regagné 2 francs à 803. La Banque d'Athènes a également haussé de 4 francs h 135.
Ici, ce matin le marché des valeurs s'est montré hésitant, indécis, aveo affaires limitées et cours généralement moins soutenus qu'hier.

LA National Bank a ouvert à 26 1/8 pour fléchir à 25 15/16 et ciôturer à 25 7/8. L'action Crédit Fonder a ouvert à 801 pour monter a 803 et clôturer à 799. La Daira est offerte à 17 5/8. La Banque d'Athènes, en bonne demande, a atteint 134.
Dans le groupe des Hôtels, les Nungovich s'inscrivent à 11 13/16; les Laehler avancent à 3 5/8 et les Anglo-American Nile 15 3/4.

Parmi les petites valeurs, les New Egyptian sont recherolées à 29 sh.; les Investment Abdy h 1 3/16. Les Estates ont fait 1 5/8 avec beaucoup de transactions. Lee Nile Cold Storage sont demandés h 0 11/16 et les Cotton Mills sont en bonne tendance à 6 sh.
On a de bonnes nouvelles an sojet de la Daira Sanieh.

Si nos informations sont exactes, le dividende de l'action fractionnée de la Société des Eaux du Caire s'élèvera, cette année, à une dizaine de francs. Il sera payé en une senle fois ao mois d'avril. On sait que, jusqn'à présent, le oonpon était payé en deux échéances : avril et ootobre.
Les recettes de la Sodété sont en progression- toujours croissante ; elles dépassent de 7,000 livres en 1905 celles de l'année 1904.

La Société a inauguré, ces temps dernier., son exploitation de la ligne Zeï-onn Matarieb. Or, oe nouveau service est appelé à prendre on grand développement et donnera certainement un bénéfice appréciable dans un avenir prochain.
Nous extrayons d'ace lettre de Londres, en date du 28 décembre, le passage suivant:

"Des envois importants d'or de la Enssie vers l'Europe occidentale et snrtont vers Berlin, ont amené sur cette place une sensible modification du change, i'oce des principales oanses des craintes récemment éprouvées par la Banque d'Angleterre. En présence de oe changement, il n'y a pins lien d'appréhender une é évation éventuelle du taux d'escompte. La tension monétaire est encore seu ible sur notre place, mai-, c'est là un effet de cau.es locales qui disparaîtront avec l'échéance de janvier.

"Les besoins de fiu d'année ont éié par tionlièrement considérables cette fois; mai- bien des demandes, qui entretiennent une certaine gène sur notre marché, oesseron dès les débat de l'entés prochaine, au moment même où les ooupons apporteront un nouveau flot de capitaux disponibles.
"Aussi bien, sanf des demandes importante- et imprévues de l'étranger, noos sommes à la veille de revoir une aisance que noos n'avons plus connue depuis longtemps."

Les cours du coton sont signalés en nouvelle hausse d'Amérique. Le disponible a gagné hier 10 peints ; le Mai et TOombre, 13 et 10 peints respectivement. Le marché de Liverpool e-t également en bonne tendance.
Ici, le Mars a ouvert ce matin à 15 5/8 ponr oiôtarer à 15 21/12.

MM. H. de Vries et Bontigny, agents de change, se chargent de l'exécation de tous ordres de Bourse (valeurs et marchandises) sur les marchés de Londres, Paris, Bruxelles, Anvers, Liverpool et Nevr-Yurk. La Circulaire quotidienne de U maison est envoyés sur deman de.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Anjour d'hnui a midi et démit)

Après au début assez ferme, notre marché a faibli sous l'impressiou des mauvaises nouvelles politiques, mais les dépêches de oe matin ayant relaté une amélioration des rapports anglo allemands, 1a fermeté n'a pas tardé a reprendre le dessus. Cependant, l'ensemble des fluctuations est plutôt en faveur de la baisse.
L'action Crédit Foncier1 atteint 805 1/2, eu hausse de 5 fr. 1/2.
Des milliers d'Agricole ont été échangés durant la matinée, ou qui a fait monter le oours à 9 9/16.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE'S SHARES.
div.p: An interesting piece of contemporary Egyptian history is told in the "Times" of the 26th nlto., by Mr. Lucien Wolf, which thoughtful Englishmen must read with somewhat mixed feelings. All's well that ends well, and our negotiations for the acquisition of the Khedive Ismail's shares in the Suez Canal ended very well indeed. Bot the story of the whole transaction, as Mr. Wolf tells it, recalls more than one blunder not creditable to our statesmanship or even to our intelligence, and more than one danger from which we escaped through no merits of our own. Lord Palmerston, as everybody knows, opposed the whole scheme for the construction of the Canal from the first, and in the eagerness of his aversion hinted that it was visionary and impracticable—a view in which be was largely supported by the great body of British opinion. That was our first mistake, and, bad not France been stricken down and impoverished by her great struggle with Germany immediately after the Canal was completed, it might have cost us dear. Our sailors, at any rate, were quick to realize the importance of the new waterway soon after it was open. Admiral Richards and General Sir Andrew Clarke drew up a report for the Admiralty in 1870, in which they recognized its significance for our commerce and for our sea power and the dangers to both which might arise, if it fell into the hands of a single State, or even into those of an independent company. But these considerations do not seem to have had much weight with the Government of Mr. Gladstone. A few months after the report was written, M. de Lesseps found himself in a most embarrassing position. The company, in which so much French money had been sunk, was on the verge of bankruptcy. The interest on the debentures was in arrear, and there were no funds to meet the next coupon but one of the ordinary shares, white the prospect still farther ahead was very black. With characteristic decision, he made up his mind to sell the undertaking to the maritime Powers, but this project, which leaked oat, proved very distasteful both to the Khedive and to the Parte. They bad a presentiment that an international administration in Egypt would not be agreeable to them, and, in order to prevent it, they suggested that England should become the sole purchaser. General Stanton, who was then our representative at Cairo, strongly pressed the Government to close with the proposal, and the Duke of Argyl, on behalf of the India Office, gave it his support. But the Cabinet appear to have resolutely shut their eyes to the larger aspects of the subject. They seem to have treated it as a purely financial matter, and they hold that it was no business of ours to "reimburse the shareholders." M. de Lesseps actually came to England to make a bargain, but Lord Granville, it is stated, refused even to discuss the offers pat forward by his agent. As M. de Lesseps could not sell to us, he attempted to sell to others, but the Porte, with our support, finally saved as from this particular danger, by placing its veto as suzerain of Egypt on all plans for sale.

The change was sharply marked in the reply of the French Ambassador to a suggestion of a possible purchase by the maritime Powers which Lord Derby made in conversation in April. The "insinuation," he affirmed, "bore no relation to the actual situation," and the Duc Decazes, then Foreign Minister, warmly approved of his answer. M. de Lesseps told Lord Rothschild that a purchase was quite out of the question, and at the same time he imprudently continued his policy of worrying British ships—even British ships of war—in the Canal.

Headed off in France, Mr. Disraeli tamed his eyes towards Egypt ; but here, again, the circumstances did not at first seem propitious. The Khedive was, of course, in want of money , he always was; but when the Rothschilds were invited to toned him in the summer of 1875, his necessities were not particularly pressing. He could still get money at a price, and he did not erectly care what price he gave for it to the obliging persons who habitually supplied him. It was the bankruptcy of his suzerain, which took place in October, that first made his policemen hopeless. The crash in Constantinople was followed by a crisis in Alexandria. A loan was the one thing necessary to save the Khedive from having to follow in the footstep, of the Sultan, and desperate were the efforts made to raise it in the time to meet the December coupons on the debt. The Khedive did his best, with this group and with that, but none of them would give him the necessary cash, even at 18 per cent., on such security as he had to offer, though one group, at least, was considering plans to buy his canal hires. It was at this time while the negotiations were still in progress, that Mr. Frederick Greenwood beard of them from Mr. Henry Oppenheim, and with remarkable courage and judgment did the country the great service of which we learnt the fall particulars from his own lips at the banquet given in his honour last spring. The Duc Decazes was disposed to sanction the purchase of the shares by one of the French syndicates but he did not venture to do so without informing Lord Derby, and Lord Derby's answer showed him that the step would be attended by serious consequences. The French offers were manifestly "off," and nothing remained for the Khedive but to make the beat bargain with England he could do. It was not a bad bargain for him, and for us it has been not only an immense financial success, but the foundation of all the work which we have done subsequently in Egypt. It is a memorable example of what may be accomplished at an opportune time by a bold and judicious violation of "precedent."

Baffled in this direction, M. de "Lesseps devoted his remarkable ingenuity to procuring money fur his shareholders in other ways. The readiest way was to raise the dues on the Canal, and the step was doubtless all the more agreeable to him because by fier the larger proportion of them was paid by British shipping. There was a trifling obstacle in the way, caused by the clause in the concession which fixed the rates at 10f. per " ton of capacity " ; but that did not arrest him. He got a commission to decide that a "ton of capacity" was some thing altogether different from what everybody had supposed it to be, and he got a French Court of Appeal to confirm this interpretation. When an international commission determined that the new charges were unjustifiable and made new regulations, he actually wrote to the British Admiralty and to the Board of Trade to say that his agents bad strict orders to enforce payment of the does approved by the company, and that ships which refused to pay must go round the Cape. It was only under a threat of eviction, supported by 10,000 Egyptian troops, that he finally yielded. Such was the state of things when Mr. Disraeli took office in February, 1874, and his old interest in the East, which had led him in his early youth to offer the Caliph his services under the command of the Pasha of Janina, at once led him to study the condition of the Ottoman Empire. By May he had made up his mind to buy the shares if he could, and in that month he sent the present Lord Rothschild to Paris to try and reopen the negotiations which Lord Granville had refused to entertain. But time is of the essence of such transactions, and the favourable moment had gone by. M. de Lesseps, it is true, was as hard up, or nearly as hard up, as ever; but between 1871 and 1874 the political aspect of the question had completely changed. France was already feeling her feet after the tremendous shock of her defeat, and there is reason, we are told, to suppose that, when the Comte de Chaudordy met Prince Gortchakoff at Interlaken in the summer of 1873, the defence of French interests in Egypt was amongst the subjects they discussed.

div.head: ARMY AND NAVY.
div.p: The home battalions of the King's Royal Rifle Corps are preparing drafts to join the 1st Battalion in Egypt next February.

Major L. F. Philips, King's Royal Rifle Corps, on promotion, has been posted to the 2nd Battalion at Ranikhet, Bengal, and placed on duty with a draft for the West Yorkshire Regiment, leaving Southampton on the 3rd February.

Lieutenant-Colonel J. R. Dyas, was has just been promoted to the command of the 2nd Battalion Royal Warwickshire Regiment, Portland, from second in command of the 1st Battalion at Quetta, was appointed to the old 67th Hampshire Regiment in January, 1881, just before the territorial system came into operation. He served with the Hampshires and as a special service officer in the Burmese War, 1885-86, and 1887-89 (mentioned in despacthces, medal with two clasps), and prior to that had a turn in the Sudan operations of 1885 (medal with clasp, and Khedive's star). He got his captiancy in the Warwicks in 1889, and was with the 1st Battalion in Kitchener's avenging march to Khartoum, including the battle of Omdurman (British medal, and Khedive's medal with clasp). The vacant majority second in command should go to Major H.R. Vaughan of the 1st Battalion.

It is stated that Mr. Haldane, the new War Secretary, will not proceed with some of his predecessor's "reforms" except under expert advice. The finest thing about Mr. Haldane is that nothing is known about him. He has no pet theories as to how the British Army should be run, and consequently he will be able to weather the rocks on which his two predecessors wrecked themselves and the army's efficiency. Of course he is a Liberal and he is a staunch Imperialist, one of the "poor toolish creatures," so named by his present chief, "C.B." Mr. Haldane has begun well by causing the return of Sir William Nicholson to the War Office.

The 2nd Battalion East Yorkshire Regiment, Brevet Colonel E.A. Ogle commancing, left Aldershot yesterday for Southampton, where it embarked on the S.S. Ionian for Bombay, which will be reached on the 19th January. From there the "Snappers" will proceed to Maymyo, Burmah. The Ionian also takes out Royal Artillery drafts and infantry drafts for Burmah and the battalions at Bellary and Bangalore. On the return voyage the Ionian will bring back the 1st Battalion of the East Yorks, leaving Bombay on the 26th January and reaching Southampton on the 16th February. The battalion will be stationed at Shorncliffe instead of Dover.

A special military commission has been appointed to consider the question of making the German cavalry invisible, or at least less conspicious, especially on the sky-line, where it would offer a good target for the enemy. Patrols and scouting parties are affected especially by this question. The authorities recognise that the question will not be solved merely by changing the too striking uniform of the men into a grey-green uniform; the horses themselves must be rendered less conspicuous. Some military experts are in favour of dyeing the horses' skin; but opinions vary greatly as to the right colour to be used in making the horses less visible. One suggestion has been made that the horses shall be screened by carrying light trappings of canvas of variety of colours.

Orders have been issued for the cruiser Black Prince, now completing at the Thames Ironworks, Blackwall, to be ready for commissioning early in April for service with the Second Cruiser Squadron, in which she will relieve the cruiser Bedford.

div.head: IN TOWN AND COUNTRY.
div.p: DR. WILLIAMS' PINK PILLS EFFECT CURES.

IN TOWN. One of the busiest ladies in the west of London is Mrs. Phillips, who manages the fashionable boarding house at 13, Fopstone road, Earl's Court. But at one time this lady was a great sufferer from sciatica and lumbago. "For years I had been subject to rheumatism," she said, "but two years ago I had an acute attack, with pains in my hip to my heel. I also had a dull, sickening pain in my back. I had decided to go into hospital, when a friend suggested that Dr. Williams' Pink Pills would cure me. With a few doses I knew that they were effecting an improvement in my health. Soon I was able to get about, and when the second box was finished I was quite cured. Since that day I have never had sciatica, lumbago, or rheumatism."

INT THE COUNTRY. Mr. George Davenport, 38, Portland st., Colne, Lancashire, has had a narrow escape from death by blood poisoning. But Dr. Williams' Pink Pills restored him to perfect health and strength. He states: - "I contracted blood poisoning and for four months I lay as if paralysed, with my nerves all shattered. I could neither sit nor stand. One day I read of Dr. Williams' Pink Pills, and sent for a box. They worked wonders, giving me appetite, strength, and new blood. A fortnight later I was a new man." Mrs. Davenport added: "Nobody thought he would ever get better; yet he is to-day in full health. A young woman at Bridge End, Colne, afflicted with St. Vitus' dance, was completely cured by Dr. Williams' Pink Pills."

Thousands of men and women in city and country praise Dr. Williams' Pink Pills, which have cured Ameamia, Indigestion, Eczema, Consumption, Kidney Disease, Bile, Rheumatism, Sciatica, St. Vitus' Darcs, Neuralgia, Paralysis, and Locomotor Ataxy. div.head: A BROKEN-DOWN SYSTEM.
div.p: This is a condition (or disease) to which doctors give many names, but which few of them really understand. It it simply weakness—a break-down, as it were, of the vital forces that sustain the system. No matter what may be its causes (for they are almost numberless), its symptoms are much the same; the more prominent being sleeplessness, sense of prostration or weariness, depression of spirits and want of energy for all the ordinary affairs of life. Now, what alone is absolutely essential in all such cases is increased vitality—vigour--
VITAL STRENGTH & ENERGY
to throw off these morbid feelings, and experience proves that as night succeeds the day this may be more certainly secured by a course of the celebrated life-reviving tonic
THERAPION No.3
than by any other known combination. So surely as it is taken in accordance with the printed directions accompanying it, will the shattered health be restored,
THE EXPIRING LAMP OF LIFE LIGHTED UP AFRESH,

and a new existence imparted in place of what had so lately seemed worn-out, "used up," and valueless. This wonderful medicament is purely vegetable and innocuous, is agreeable to the taste —suitable for all constitutions and conditions, in either sex; and it is difficult to imagine a case of disease or derangement, whose main features are those of debility, that will not be speedily and permanently benefited by this never-failing recuperative essence, which is destined to cast into oblivion everything that had preceded it for this wide-spread and numerous class of human ailments.
THERAPION

is sold by the principal Chemists throughout the world. Price in England, 2 9 and 4/6. Purchasers should see that the word 'THERAPION' appears on British Government Stamp (in white letters on a red ground) affixed to every package by order of His Majesty's Hon. div.p: Société Anonyme
Capital 250,000,000 de francs
Entièrement Versés
Agences d'Égypte:
Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
